answer_html: And so we see that function is concave up on the intervals (\(-\infty\), 1) and (3, \(+\infty\)) while it is concave down on the interval (1,3).
answer_latex:
And so we see that function is concave up on the intervals ($-\infty$,
1) and (3, $+\infty$) while it is concave down on the interval (1,3).
hints_html: This was pretty much computed two problems ago. Use the second derivative and then make a sign chart.
hints_latex:
This was pretty much computed two problems ago. Use the second
derivative and then make a sign chart.
hints_raw: This was pretty much computed two problems ago. Use the second derivative and then make a sign chart.
question: 4 (v)
sols_html:
In part iii) of this question we obtained the sign table of the second derivative:

[c]@llllll@ & & \(\displaystyle 1\) & & \(\displaystyle 3\) &
\(\displaystyle 3(x-1)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle (x-3)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f(x)\) & \(\displaystyle \cup\) & & \(\displaystyle \cap\) & & \(\displaystyle \cup\)

And so we see that function is concave up on the intervals (\(-\infty\), 1) and (3, \(+\infty\)) while it is concave down on the interval (1,3).
sols_latex:
In
{part
\emph{iii)} of this question} we obtained the sign table of the second
derivative:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& & $\displaystyle 1$ & & $\displaystyle 3$ &\\
$\displaystyle 3(x-1)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle (x-3)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \cup$ & & $\displaystyle \cap$ &
& $\displaystyle \cup$\\\\
\end{longtable}

And so we see that function is concave up on the intervals ($-\infty$,
1) and (3, $+\infty$) while it is concave down on the interval (1,3).

And so we see that function is concave up on the intervals (-&infin;, 1) and (3, +&infin;) while it is concave down on the interval (1,3).
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

v) Determine the interval(s) for which f(x) is concave up and concave down, respectively.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.
</math>

v) Determine the interval(s) for which f(x) is concave up and concave down, respectively.
